section: Additional Visa Programs and Settlement Information

visaPrograms_continued.popularity: High for IT and Engineering professionals

overview.description: Work and residence permit for highly qualified professionals. Fast track to permanent residence (just 2 years). Requires university degree or 5 years professional experience and high salary threshold.
keyBenefits: Work in any EU country after 18 months
Lower salary threshold than other EU countries

salaryThresholds.note: Threshold updates annually based on average national salary

option1.requirement: 3+ years higher education degree (Bachelor's or higher)
option1.recognition: Turkish degree must be relevant to job position

option2.requirement: 5+ years professional experience in relevant field
option2.notes: Can substitute for university degree (new 2024 EU directive)

employmentRequirements.jobOffer: Must have valid employment contract, mandate contract, or specific work contract
employmentRequirements.salary: Must meet or exceed minimum threshold (PLN 12,272.60 gross/month in 2025)

languageRequirements.notes: No official Polish or English language requirement for visa, but needed for work

applicationProcess.note: Processing time varies significantly by voivodeship

steps.description: Find employer in Poland willing to sponsor Blue Card
tips: IT sector has highest demand
Remote work becoming more common
Salary negotiation important to meet threshold

steps.description: Polish employer prepares work contract and supporting documents
Apply at Polish embassy in Turkey or in Poland if legally present
steps.location: Polish Embassy Ankara or Consulate, OR voivodeship office in Poland

steps.notes: Legal stay if submitted in Poland; decision is sent by post

pathToPermanentResidency.process: After 2 years continuous employment with Blue Card, can apply for permanent residence
pathToPermanentResidency.notes: One of shortest paths to PR in EU

visaPrograms_continued.officialName: Work Permit Type A (Zezwolenie na pracę typu A)

overview.description: Standard work permit for foreign workers with employer sponsorship. Suitable for most professions not qualifying for Blue Card.
keyBenefits: No minimum salary requirement (vs Blue Card)
Available for wide range of professions

employmentRequirements.jobOffer: Valid employment contract from Polish employer
employmentRequirements.employerObligation: Employer must apply for work permit before employee arrives
employmentRequirements.laborMarketTest: Employer must advertise position in Poland first (some exceptions)

applicationProcess.whoApplies: Employer applies on behalf of employee

steps.description: Employer advertises position to Polish/EU workers first
steps.notes: Required unless position qualifies for exemption

steps.description: Employer submits work permit application to local labor office (Urząd Pracy)
After work permit approved, employee applies for D visa at embassy

decision1_80Benefits.year1: After 1 year legal employment: right to renew work permit with same employer
decision1_80Benefits.year3: After 3 years legal employment: can work in same profession with any employer
decision1_80Benefits.notes: Special rights under Turkey-EEC Association Agreement

firstWeekChecklist.deadline: Within 30 days of arrival (EU citizens); immediately for non-EU
firstWeekChecklist.description: Register your residential address at local municipal office
firstWeekChecklist.location: Urząd Miasta (Municipal Office) or Urząd Gminy (Commune Office) in your area
tips: Landlord may need to accompany you or provide signed consent
This triggers automatic PESEL number assignment
Bring original documents plus copies
firstWeekChecklist.consequences: Required for PESEL, bank account, residence permit application

firstWeekChecklist.deadline: Automatic with address registration if staying 30+ days
firstWeekChecklist.description: Polish national identification number - essential for everything
firstWeekChecklist.location: Automatically assigned when registering address, OR apply separately at any municipal office
firstWeekChecklist.estimatedTime: Immediate (if with address registration) or 1-2 days
tips: PESEL is 11 digits - memorize it!
Needed for: bank account, SIM card, work, healthcare, taxes
Free to obtain, small fee only for written certificate
firstWeekChecklist.consequences: Cannot function in Poland without PESEL - needed for almost everything

firstWeekChecklist.description: Local phone number essential for communication and verification
tips: Prepaid SIM doesn't require PESEL
Contract plans need PESEL and address registration
Buy at official stores for activation help

firstWeekChecklist.description: Polish bank account needed for salary, rent, bills

recommendedBanks.name: Bank Millennium
recommendedBanks.pros: Easy process for foreigners, good app

requiredDocuments: Proof of address (rental agreement or registration confirmation)
tips: Some banks allow account opening without PESEL but it's harder
Bring employment contract if you have one
Ask for debit card and online banking activation
Most banks have English-speaking staff in big cities

firstWeekChecklist.description: Rechargeable card for buses, trams, metro
firstWeekChecklist.location: Metro stations, kiosks, public transport information points

Warsaw.howToPurchase: At metro stations, kiosks with 'ZTM Warszawa' sign

tips: Monthly pass much cheaper than daily tickets
Student discount available with ISIC card or student ID
Download city transport app for route planning

firstWeekChecklist.notes: Brings specific to-do items from institution

firstMonthChecklist.deadline: Within 45 days of arrival with D visa
firstMonthChecklist.description: Convert D visa to temporary residence permit
firstMonthChecklist.location: Voivodeship Office (Urząd Wojewódzki) in your region
requiredDocuments: Application form (available at office or online)
firstMonthChecklist.legalStayDuringProcessing: Yes - your stay is legal while waiting
tips: Book appointment online to avoid long waits
Bring all original documents plus copies
Get receipt - it proves legal stay
Fingerprints will be taken

firstMonthChecklist.description: Register for Polish public healthcare (if working) or maintain private insurance

whoIsEligible.students: Can buy voluntary NFZ insurance at student rate
whoIsEligible.others: Must have private insurance or voluntary NFZ

tips: Employees: employer handles NFZ registration automatically
Students: private insurance often cheaper than NFZ
Keep insurance proof always

firstMonthChecklist.location: Local Tax Office (Urząd Skarbowy) or online
firstMonthChecklist.howToApply: Fill form (NIP-7 for individuals) at tax office
firstMonthChecklist.notes: Employer may handle this; free to obtain

platforms: OLX.pl (most popular, be careful of scams)
tips: Never pay before seeing apartment
Verify landlord identity
Get written contract
Typical deposit: 1-2 months rent
Bills usually separate from rent
Check condition and take photos

housingMarket.overview: Poland has affordable housing compared to Western Europe. Rental market active in all major cities. Long-term contracts (12 months) most common.

rentalMarket.utilitiesNote: Usually paid separately - expect 300-500 PLN/month for utilities
tenantRights: Rent increases limited during contract period
Deposit must be returned within 1 month after move-out
commonPitfalls: OLX scams - never pay before viewing
Deposit disputes - document apartment condition with photos
Utility bills - clarify who pays what
Contract language - get Polish friend to review if needed

scamWarnings: Never wire money before seeing apartment
Request to meet in person (scammers avoid this)
